title: 114_s3160
content: The Act may be cited as the "Securing our Secrets Act" or the "SOS Act". Definitions are provided in Section 2. In this Act, key definitions are provided including terms like "appropriate congressional committees," "Department," "infraction," "Inspector General," and "intelligence community." The curr_chunk provides definitions for "intelligence community" and "Secretary" as per the National Security Act of 1947. SEC. 3. USE OF NONGOVERNMENTAL INFORMATION SYSTEMS. Employees of the Department must use only Department-owned electronic communication systems for work-related communications. The Secretary must certify annually that all employees have access to these systems. If certification cannot be made, a report must be provided to the appropriate congressional committees. Employees of the Department must use Department-owned electronic communication systems for work-related communications. The Secretary must certify annually that all employees have access to these systems. If certification cannot be made, a report must be provided to congressional committees detailing the number of employees lacking access, reasons for the lack of access, steps taken to ensure access, and measures for recording and reviewing work-related electronic communications. The Secretary of State may waive requirements for using Department-owned electronic communication systems for one employee or a group of up to 10 employees if it is in the foreign policy or national security interest of the United States. All work-related communications on nongovernmental systems must be archived according to the Federal Records Act. The Secretary of State can waive electronic communication system requirements for up to 10 employees if it serves US foreign policy or national security interests. Waivers must be justified in writing to Congress and can last up to 180 days, with the option for reissuance. The Inspector General must establish an oversight plan within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Inspector General must develop an oversight plan within 90 days to ensure compliance with the requirements by the Secretary and Department employees. SEC. 4. REPORT ON SECURITY REVIEWS AND VIOLATIONS. The Secretary must submit an annual report detailing security violations, including unauthorized transfer of classified information, naming responsible employees, violation dates, descriptions, compromised information indication, violated laws, and actions taken in response. The annual report must include details of security violations, such as unauthorized transfer of classified information, employee names, violation dates, compromised information, violated laws, and actions taken in response. The report must also ensure privacy protection under the Privacy Act of 1974. SEC. 5. CLASSIFIED INFORMATION SPILLAGE. SEC. 5 outlines the procedures for detecting classified information spillage, including appointing officials for training and randomized sampling. The Inspector General is responsible for auditing this work and reporting findings to congressional committees. SEC. 6 addresses remedial training. The Secretary must certify that all Department personnel with security clearances have completed emergency refresher training on handling classified information, including rules for electronic transmission and derivative classification. The Secretary must ensure the protection of classified information by addressing various aspects such as handling foreign government information, processing FOIA requests, reviewing classification challenges, and safeguarding disclosed classified information. The Secretary must comply with Executive Order 13526 by demonstrating personal commitment, allocating resources, optimizing information sharing, and designating a senior official to administer classified information programs. The program must be designed and maintained to optimize sharing and safeguarding of classified information, designate a senior agency official to administer it, include classified information management in personnel evaluations, explain penalties for violations, and require a signed certification of understanding and compliance from employees. Employees with security clearances are required to undergo emergency refresher training prioritized based on clearance levels. The Secretary has the authority to delay training for up to 30 days for critical foreign policy reasons. The Secretary can delay training for employees with security clearances for up to 30 days if critical foreign policy interests require it. Applicable rules and procedures include federal statutes, Executive Order 13526, other executive orders on classified information, the Foreign Affairs Manual, and Departmental guidance. The Secretary must establish a training program within 180 days to prevent mishandling of intelligence information by Department employees. This program will cover the transfer of classified or sensitive information to unauthorized systems and compliance with security standards. Additionally, a plan for reforming the response to information requests and archiving is required. The Secretary must submit a plan within 90 days for completing reforms related to identifying classified information in documents under the Freedom of Information Act. This plan includes training employees and ensuring proper classification procedures. The plan must include procedures for officials to determine the classification status of information, a training program on archiving electronic communications, and an annual affidavit certifying proper document archiving. The employee must ensure all documents are archived in compliance with relevant laws. The Inspector General will report on the Secretary's implementation of the archiving plan within a year of the Act's enactment.
